reviewText:
Played this game back in the day tons of times. Good memories.

The good:

Graphics are a later Unreal Engine so they aren't bad.
Highly customizable loadout that is made available to you as you progress through the levels with experience.
A very detailed upgrade model based on experience and types of shots made. You gain experience points based on the shot you make, be it close quarter, long-range, assault mode, etc. Each shot gains you XP points for a specific type of ladder and each ladder (CQB, assaulter, marksman) has its own rewards and perks.
Very good cover, concealment, shoot and peek controls. You can crouch or stand by a corner or behind cover, peek out and shoot, or peek out with zoom in function already selected, shoot, peek and go back to your zoomed view on your weapon without having to zoom in simply because you went into cover. Very useful when shooting multiple enemies from one location.
You can choose an array of weapons, armour and equipment.
When you have the gameplay mechanics downpat, it becomes super fun breaching and using different tactics when clearing rooms.

The Bad:

The AI is at times inept. They take forever sometimes to follow through with commands once you give them.
The AI cannot throw a grenade competently. Frequently I've given the command for my squad to throw a grenade at a precise location, only to watch it bounce off a wall and land back at my squad and wipe everyone out. At certain times they will refuse to even throw one when requested.
AI does not auto-heal itself. I have to backtrack and tell one AI squad member to heal another. Duh.


Very fun as you're able to plan your approach differently - either going in assault-mode or silent.
Overall it's a fun game well-intentioned hampered by some AI problems.
Worth the download if it's on sale.

7.5/10

Prepare to see a lot of [SPAS 12] and maybe a little bit of [UMP-45] on the killfeed.
You're the one getting killed by the way.

I played the 360 version of this game like 7-8 yrs ago and I pumped a LOT of hours into this game and it still manages to keep me amused. There are two things that make this game so much fun. T-Hunt (preferably with friends, realistic and high enemy density) and Customization.

T-Hunt is pretty self-explanatory, there are a set number of terrorists per map and you'll have to hunt them all down. Sometimes it's easier said than done because most of those terrorists are insanely accurate and deadly especially the infamous SPAS-12 wielding terrorists.

One of the greatest parts of this game is that there's a good amount of customization options for your character. You will gain XP from every kill and then eventually you'll start to gain more ranks and that means more options to customize your character with different armor, clothing and camos. Customizing your character is addicting as hell and it's kinda nice to see what kind of operators other players have made. There are of course those who run with their vomit colored tanktops looking like they are running towards the nearest convenience store getting their latest fix of their favourite energy drink. But hey, who am I to judge? If that's the character you want to create then so be it.

You'll also unlock more weapons and slight XP boosts through the system called A.C.E.S" this game has. There are three A.C.E.S trees called Marksman

reviewText:
The latest in Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Saga, it is truly a blast to play.
Take the lead of a small group of spec op's as they raid the most corrupt parts of Sin City.

The gunplay and control mechanics are where this game shines.
Each gun feels and sounds as it should.
You can give you squad commands to open/hold fire, raid rooms with flash/frag grenades and more!

Playing on Realistic mode is the way to go because everyone responds to the bullet locations as they would in real life, including you.

The game itself is amazing and I really enjoy it, but I can't jump up and down recommending the PC port.
Ubisoft has a pretty solid track record of buggy PC ports, this one is no different. At a lot of times I found my squad not responding. However if you're good a shooting you can still progress in the game.

I recommend it for fans of Tom Clancy's franchises and of military shooters.

7.5/10

reviewText:
A strategic, tactical FPS, this is not really the kind of game you want to play solo. While it can be done (and several do so rather fondly and have a blast), this games true potential shines with the Multi-player and character creation system.

Offering 7 chapters of campaign mayhem with anywhere from three to six checkpoints, there's easily 72+ hours of gameplay if you simply try to rush through it without fully trying to enjoy the game.

The Terrorist Hunt mode offers a chance to futher hone your skills and tactics for both Campaign and Online Versus modes. AI can vary from downright predictable, to completely unforgiving and brutal. Even on the lowest difficulty, the AI can stiff offer a variety of commentary and skill to throw down against the player. Again, trust not the AI paired up with you, BRING A FRIEND. Playing on Hunt? BRING THREE FRIENDS. The higher you set the scale, the harder this game can mess with you.

The ability to semi-realistically alter your loadouts armor-wise is amazing. The better the armor, the heavier it is, and the slower your character can move, while taking more hits (aside from the ever annoying headshot or grenade). With multiple options for gear and weaponry, you'll be hard pressed to find someone that looks exactly alike. Word to the wise, try to pick a bright color, the enemy tends to stick to darker camo options, and you don't want to be confused for an enemy at long distances.

Like any game, it does have it's quirks and glitches. Getting hit from long range with a shotgun (and it being a headshot) is downright evil. The bots also seem to have a better grasp on bullet penetration and just how to throw grenades. They also tend to spawn in random places during the Terrorist Hunts, so any areas you might have cleared, are not 100% clear. Always check your six.


Definitely more than one way to complete the game, and with the option to replay quite literally from any checkpoint in the campaign, there is always something to do. If nothing else, there's always room for improvement, and even the veterans can be caught off-guard by a trick you develop. This game does deliver.

reviewText: Rainbow Six: Vegas 2 is a game I'm very passionate about, from wonderful memories playing with my dearest of  friends, to the excitement I feel whenever I rank up and unlock more equipment. Speaking of equipment, this game offers a fairly complex  loadout customization system, probably one of the most indepth systems I've ever seen in a videogame to date, though the actual avatar creator leaves much to be desired from. (Only allowing you to chose a pre-made set of skins, gender, and war paint) Gear isn't the only thing to unlock either, weapons are another aspect to look forward to, the game offers a selection from light support guns, sniper rifles, assault/battle rifles, handguns, and sub-machine guns, not to mention grenades as well as other explosive devices of varying type, making replayability quite fun, getting to create a new gear set, and try out a new weapon. The campaign can be seen as quite straightforward, though my nostalgia blinded eyes believe it's something quite special, I'll leave the decision up to you whether it's one of a kind, or generic. Besides the main story campaign, there's a fairly run of the mill multiplayer, though with the benefit of you getting to use your custom geared loadout, and a mode called 'terrorist hunt' which is a blast to play with your buddies or even just solo, as you select a map, and clear out a set number of enemy combatants, this mode is great for grinding! The soundtrack is enjoyable to listen to, the enemy A.I is somewhat competent, the guns (dependant on which you use) sound meaty and powerful, there's also fairly realistic gameplay, even if you chose the beefiest of armour, a few well placed shots from really any weapon is going to send to you to the grave, creating adrenaline filled tense moments, which could end up with a single bullet to your head, or the enemy's. All in all, I strongly recommend this game, it's a lot of fun, and should keep you busy for a while!\n\nI hope my review can help you decide whether or not this is the game for you! ^-^

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing. Me and my best friend used to play the original for 360 all the time just for the all-mighty T-HUNT feature.

NOTE: My review is based off of my MULTIPLAYER experience, I only toyed around with the SP for a level or two on the 360 version and immediately left to go T-Hunt.

Now let's get to the real reason people buy R6V, Terrorist Hunt;
Terrorist Hunting is when a set group of terrorists (the amount is also changed by the difficulty along with their skill level) is scattered around a small map and your job is to neutralize all of them without dying. Rules can differ by how you choose to approach the set-up. If you play it offline, you can play with bot teammates, or as a lone-wolf. However, if you choose to play as a lonewolf, when you die, you die and you start back at the beginning. If you play with teammates, you can revive each other. On the online version, servers usually allowed 1 to 2 respawns with a 2-4 player team from normal to very hard settings (the amount of respawns depends on the difficulty settings). You get XP for neutralizing the enemy and winning the round. Other than playing the story co-operatively online, this is about as much teamwork as you can get on an online shooter besides playing a competitive match on CS:GO.

You can rank up your character and unlock new weapons, attachments, gear, and articles of clothing like the last edition. In my opinion not much has changed from the last R6V other than the storyline, and some of the maps (although the great Calypso Casino is still there).

If you choose to play the game strictly for the campaign, it has favorable ratings, but the game is definitely hinted at for it's T-Hunt feature. The usual DM, TDM, etc. are also availible but not often played as much as T-Hunt.

If you are able to pick this game up cheap, please do. The player base is great, but very small and shrinking heavily, and a lot of the times you are paired with someone from a country thousands of miles away. However, do not for you can T-Hunt offline as well although it might feel a little less rewarding as you're unable to show off.

All in all I would give the game a 8.9/10.
DEFINITELY 100% RECOMMENDED.

The game is amazing and the engine is beginning to show it's age but was something truely spectacular at the time, and the game is still a marvel. I hope you enjoy this great classic as much as my friends and I have.

reviewText:
Though certainly not the first game series to become worse with each new iteration, it seems that has been the trend with Rainbow Six for some time. However, even the mediocre Vegas 1 was pretty fun with it's four player co-op mode, and while a lot of the tactical elements were stripped away, we were still left with a competent, and occassionally intelligent shooter.

Vegas 2 seems to take those few things that I really enjoyed about the first, removes them, and focuses more on the things that made the first Vegas not very good to begin with. Gone is four player co-op campaign (inexplicably reduced to two player), the ability to customize your soldier right out of the box (for the PC version), and decent map design. Instead, what we get was a tedious and unneccessary progression system of unlocks, AI that seems to wildly alternate between being braindead and clairvoyant, and weaker PC optimization. And not that anyone plays a Tom Clancy game for the story, but for this one, they didn't even write a new script; instead it's the same moronic terrorist attack on Las Vegas, but following a different group of Rainbows, this one even less interesting that the last.

I can't think of one thing that was improved in this sequel, and a large amount of content was made worse. A lazy sequel to a mediocre game, and a lazy port for an almost entirely consolized series. My advice: if you want a good Rainbow Six game, try the original three, or if you want a less tactical game, play the original Vegas. There's nothing here that isn't offered in any of those games, and generally it is done in a way that is far less frustrating.

reviewText:
This game has two faces so bare with me for this one:

I love playing this game.
It's fun, exciting, descent graphics, good sound (their is a !!! large warning !!! about this though, more about that later)

Both the single player and multieplayer are fun to play with and things like terrorist hunt where you can multieplayer with up to 4 people with your friends to swipe a level of terrorist never gets old. Their are some minor annoyances of jittersish AI behavior: sometimes they react very slowly and other times they virtually 'teleport' around the corner and make an instant headshot. But it's more then workable, the game is beatable and enjoyable even through this.

You can customize your character a lot. Their are a whole range of skins, face features (mustaches, beards eyes) and that is just the face and body. You can equip different weapon sets per game and outfit your character with stuff you can unlock through gaining levels.

This leveling element has been flashed out well, their is a lot to unlock. It doesn't feel tedious because the game is well playable without a lot of unlocks. And it feels rewarding, it is just plain fun to see new stuff become available and show off your rank as well as your individual levels on assualt, CBQ and marksmen tactics.

The single player has a descent story and some interesting voice acting. It's no grande feast of fully inspired epic dialog and plot. But it's very enjoyable. Sometimes it takes a bit of good luck to get your AI colleges going and doing what they need to do, but again: it is more then workable and doesn't really halt the game in my opinion.

I would love to keep playing this game, although their one big BUT:
Their is a persistent sound bug that keeps popping up, mainly in multieplayer . The bug seams to trigger when their is full automatic gun fire (which their is almost constantly in a heated battle) and has a chance to keep looping.

Imagine the rattling of an M16 or AK rifle and that it just keeps stuck. Mostly it's a gun causing the problem laying on the ground, if you can find it and pick it up it mostly disappears.
But I also found a similar bug that isn't fixable through this and in general gets worse. The former bug is location bound, when you move away the sound is gone. This big however keeps going in any part of the game (in-agem, loading screen, main menu) and can even carry on inside your operating system. I am NOT kidding, I have tried to find the volume of the game in the Win7 volume control to mute it, disabled and enabled my sound card, but the only thing that works is rebooting your whole machine.

Now you might think, what does this rattling about a bug have to do in a review. Well, I am not the only one that has this bug. This bug is widely known and many, many users experience it. Their are a multietude of 'solutions' but nothing seams to stick. We have widely different system and have since we started playing all upgraded our machines or bought new ones, but the bugs stay. The internet is littered with forums etc that are filled with people with the same problem, but never a solid solution is provided.

I do not understand how they have been able to make a game based on the Unreal Engine that is this flawed in the audio department. You might argue that this game is a bit older, but I don't see it that way. This game has an active community and has a lot of stuff to unlock that you can only achieve by playing it a hell of a lot. In that regard I am very disappointing in both this game and Ubisoft for not providing the community with either a statement or a solution.

If this game didn't have said bug, it would be an instance classic and in my opinion can go through the decades like Unreal Tournament 2K4, Medal of Honor: Pacific Assualt, Quake 3 Arena and Battle Field 1942.

It's really a game you can pick up where you left off, have a whole lot of fun, but their is always room for improvement. A pure skill game that doesn't have game mechanics that just throw off the game balance like the new COD: Modern Warfare or the newer UT and Quake games that just didn't feel like anything we loved about the orginal format.

For me Rainbow Six was always a miss, because the AI was terribly stupid and the game very hard to learn in general. This game isn't, I really enjoy playing it and explore everything it has. But for some reason I have to accept that I will have to endure regular persistent automatic gun fire blazing through my headphones that NEVER STOP.

reviewText:
I'm reviewing this purely based on the 'Terrorist Hunt' mode; which could be a game in itself. To me, Rainbow Six Vegas 2 was the last great military FPS. In a market flooded with Call Of Duty and Battlefield and (to an extent) ARMA, Rainbow Six Vegas 2 stands out to me as the most fun, replayable game of all of them.
Playing Terrorist Hunt is a massively tense solo experience and a brilliantly funny multiplayer experience. No matter how you play, this game accommodates for your style.
It will make you think slowly and strategically about your actions, something that modern FPSs seem to have completely forgotten about. The innovative mechanics, such as rappelling, ropes and ladders add a degree of verticality to the maps, making them replayable to an almost infinite extent.
If you have (somehow) never played this game, you owe it to yourself to experience one of the greatest and most original first person shooters of this generation.

Though an older game, Rainbow Six Vegas 2 has endured despite its poor graphics and sound. The challenging yet satisfying gameplay never fails to please me even after playing the game for nearly six years. This game offers a quality single-player story, and extends the experience with the various Adversarial modes or the cooperative mode, Terrorist Hunt (Which in my opinion is the best portion of the game). I consider this game to be greatly underrated and certainly worth a play, while the unconventional controls make the game difficukt to grasp at first, once you've got the hang of it the game will become a challenging experience with tremendous replay value.

TL;DR
+Realistic and challenging gameplay
+Good story
+Fantastic Co-Op
+Very high replay value
-Bizzarre controls
-Poor graphics and sound

Though an older game, Rainbow Six Vegas 2 has endured despite its poor graphics and sound. The challenging yet satisfying gameplay never fails to please me even after playing the game for nearly six years. This game offers a quality single-player story, and extends the experience with the various Adversarial modes or the cooperative mode, Terrorist Hunt (Which in my opinion is the best portion of the game). I consider this game to be greatly underrated and certainly worth a play, while the unconventional controls make the game difficukt to grasp at first, once you've got the hang of it the game will become a challenging experience with tremendous replay value.

TL;DR
+Realistic and challenging gameplay
+Good story
+Fantastic Co-Op
+Very high replay value
-Bizzarre controls
-Poor graphics and sound
-Rough gameplay
